organisms.Name: Boulder Brain Coral
organisms.Desc: Animal that can live for over 250 years.Polyps emerge at night and retract inside the hard-coral skeleton during the daytime. Threatened by: predation of stoplight parrotfish and three-spot damselfish and raising seawater temperatures that leads to coral bleaching.

organisms.Name: Staghorn Coral
organisms.Desc: Used to be the dominant coral on Caribbean reefs until the 1980s, the population declined 97% from white band disease. Colonial corals reproduce asexually when branches break off a colony and reattach to the substrate.

organisms.Name: Elkhorn Coral
organisms.Desc: Due to their branching structure, this coral provides a habitat and shelter for reef wildlife. Provide storm surge protection by absorbing the energy of storm waves. Threatened by warming waters of the ocean that contributes to coral bleaching.

organisms.Name: Atlantic Long-Finned Squid
organisms.Desc: Short-lived species (~9 months) that have been targeted along the northeastern coast of the US since the 1880s, first as bait and now as food for humans and bait.

organisms.Name: Banded Arm Brittle Star
organisms.Desc: Feed nocturnally on decomposed organic material. Can regenerate their arms if attacked by predators.

organisms.Name: Sand Dollar
organisms.Desc: Eat microogranisms and algae with their tube feet. Sense light and temperature by the abundance of sensory cells on the epidermis.

organisms.Name: Trumpetfish
organisms.Desc: Diurnal fish that only hunt in the daytime to hide from prey with the shadows of the reef. Ambush predatory fish that remain motionless and pipette feeds the prey through suction

organisms.Name: Rainbow Runner
organisms.Desc: Fast-swimming carnivorous fish that are highly migratory. Prey consists of small fish, cephlaopods, and planktonic crustaceans.

organisms.Name: Blue Tang
organisms.Desc: Herbivorous fish that continuously feed on the algae of coral reefs and other surrounding fish. Symbiotic relationship.

organisms.Name: Blue Striped Grunt
organisms.Desc: The grunt travels in schools (up to 1000 grunts) with the French grunt. Feed on shrimp, bivalves, and crustaceans.

organisms.Name: Banded Butterflyfish
organisms.Desc: Mainly travel in pairs but can form large schools. Parasite cleaners to other fish. Reproduce through broadcast spawning: female releases egg at the same time as male releases sperm in the water column above the coral reef.

organisms.Name: Long Spined Sea Urchin
organisms.Desc: Graze algae off coral reefs to prevent overgrowth. Have an average lifespan of 6-8 years.

organisms.Name: Forbes Sea Star
organisms.Desc: Carnviorous echinoderm that feeds on invertebrates, molluscan bivalves, and gastropods. Reach sexual matury at 2-5 years old and live to about 35 years.

organisms.Name: Common Sea Fan
organisms.Desc: Filter feeds on planktons. The purple color comes from chemical pigments produced in the spicules. Reproduce by cloning or fragmentation.

organisms.Name: Angular Sea Whip
organisms.Desc: Photosynthetic, flattened blade-like branches where white or tan polyps (containing zooxanthellae) merge along the edges.

organisms.Name: Moon Jellyfish
organisms.Desc: Almost entirely translucent jellyfish that respies by diffusing oxygen from water through thin membrane covering body. Food source for Ocean Sunfish, Leatherback Sea Turtle, and other bigger jellyfish. Plastic bags can be mistaken for these jellyfish.

organisms.Name: Branching Vase Sponge
organisms.Desc: Suspension feeders on plankton that filter out of water currents, contributes to water column productivity.

organisms.Name: Lightning Whelk
organisms.Desc: Take 10-20 years to grow 8 inches in length. Predatory whelk that feed mostly on bivalves. Native Americans used the shells for tools, jewelry making, and ornaments.
